title: Decision Theory and Rational Choice
description: Foundations of decision theory and how Active Inference provides a normative theory of decision making under uncertainty.
learning_objectives: Understand normative theories of decision making
Apply expected utility theory to decision problems
Connect decision theory to Active Inference

content.overview: Decision theory provides the normative foundation for rational choice under uncertainty. Active Inference extends decision theory by providing a principled account of how agents learn and represent their preferences.

axioms.completeness: For any two outcomes x,y, either x ≻ y, y ≻ x, or x ∼ y
axioms.transitivity: If x ≻ y and y ≻ z, then x ≻ z
axioms.independence: If x ≻ y, then px + (1-p)z ≻ py + (1-p)z for any z and p ∈ (0,1]
axioms.continuity: If x ≻ y ≻ z, then there exists p such that y ∼ px + (1-p)z

expected_utility_theory.utility_function: u(x) - numerical representation of preferences satisfying u(x) > u(y) iff x ≻ y

von_neumann_morgenstern.theorem: Under the axioms, preferences can be represented by expected utility
von_neumann_morgenstern.uniqueness: Utility function unique up to positive linear transformation
von_neumann_morgenstern.risk_attitude: Concave u(x) implies risk aversion, convex implies risk seeking

risk_measures.decreasing_risk_aversion: A'(x) < 0 common for wealth utility functions

subjective_expected_utility.bayesian_decision_theory: Decisions based on subjective expected utility

prospect_theory.value_function: v(x) = x^α for gains, -λ(-x)^β for losses
prospect_theory.probability_weighting: w(p) ≠ p - overweighting of small probabilities
prospect_theory.loss_aversion: λ > 1 - losses hurt more than gains help
prospect_theory.reference_dependence: Outcomes evaluated relative to reference point

active_inference_decision_making.expected_free_energy: G(π) = expected cost of policy π

decision_problem.outcomes: Set of possible outcomes X = {x₁, x₂, ..., xₙ}
decision_problem.actions: Set of available actions A = {a₁, a₂, ..., aₘ}
decision_problem.consequences: Function f: A → X mapping actions to outcomes
decision_problem.preferences: Binary relation ≻ over outcomes satisfying rationality axioms

utility_representation.utility_function: u: X → ℝ satisfying u(x) > u(y) iff x ≻ y

common_misconceptions.clarification: Behavioral economics shows systematic departures from rationality; prospect theory explains many observed biases

common_misconceptions.misconception: Expected utility is the only rational theory
common_misconceptions.clarification: Active Inference provides alternative normative accounts that incorporate information-seeking behavior
Rational decision making works with uncertainty and can value information acquisition
Expected utility, prospect theory, and expected free energy make different predictions and have different scopes
Utilities are subjective and must be inferred from behavior or elicited through careful methods
Risk aversion can be rational in the presence of background risk or when facing non-linear utility
